text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? WITH A RADIO? OR OF 10 MILES?

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? NEARLY EVERY SUMMER DURING

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days? ALWAYS SUNDAYS

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? NEVER STOPPED FOR PARTY

What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? MORNING, CAME HOME EARLY TO DO HOUSEWORK

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? USUALLY - ALL HANDS PITCHED IN TO HELP

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to make porridge used, or was some other expression common?) "SITTING FOLKS THERE'S LOTS OF GRAVY"

And there usually was plenty made with milk from Fried Pork

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? ALWAYS COFFEE, BREAD, BUTTER AND SOMETIMES LOG BUILDINGS ALSO QUILTS

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? USUALLY THE WHOLE FAMILY

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? YES WHEN PUTTING UP LOG BUILDINGS ALSO QUILTS

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. THE BEES WERE NOT REGULAR AS THEY WERE USUALLY FOR SOMEONE IN NEED AND CALLED AS THE OCCASION

7. In the earliest years that you were here were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. BABIES AND YOUNG CHILDREN ON BEDS THAT WERE LEFT UP. MUST BEDS BE TAKEN DOWN TO MAKE ROOM AND HAD TO BE PUT UP BEFORE WE COULD RETIRE AFTER GUESTS WERE THERE MORE FREQUENT IN LATER YEARS? GIVE DATES.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, once a week, once every two weeks, once a month, etc.? ABOUT 2 AT EACH HOUSE, IN WINTER, IN SUMMER.
PIONEER RECOLLECTIONS AND SOCIAL LIFE.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were there enough for you for visiting base and nearby? How many homes were there enough for you for visiting base and nearby? How many homes were there enough for you for visiting base and nearby?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Nearly every Sunday during the summer.

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Always Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We often stopped for a chat, but not for dinner.

5. What time of day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Morning came home early to do chores.

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually, all hands pitched in to help.

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "make yourself at home" used, or was some other expression common?)

8. Usually the whole family came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity. Yes, when putting up log buildings. Also quilts.

9. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, telling dates if possible, telling what the "teas" were for, and how often they occurred.

10. The "teas" were not regular as they were usually for some one in need and called as the occasion arose.

11. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. Practically all house parties.

12. Was it more work taken down to make room and had to be put up before we could retire after guests were there?

13. Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

14. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, once a week, once a month, etc.?

15. About 2 at each house, in winter, in summer.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

VARY LITTLE. PARTIES AT OUR HOMES. CHRISTMAS TREE STAND IN A NEW STORE BUILDING. AND TREE IN WAUCHOPP VILLAGE SCHOOL. 3RD TREE THE NEW METHODIST CHURCH WAUCHOPP. WE CALLED THE GATHERINGS SPORTS DAYS OR PICNICS. HAD EVERYONE RUN RACES. PLAYED GAMES. TOOK OFF FOR ETC.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

NOT VERY MUCH. SCHOOL WAS FOR THE CHILDREN TO BE TAUGHT IN NOT FOR PLAYING

9. When was your first community hall built? 1912.

What material was it made of? CEMENT. How large was it? 20x40=800 sq ft.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? JOHN BRAGSTROM OF WAUCHOPP ARK ESTATE. DRAKER AND JACK OF ALL TRADES. MY UNCLE.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? IN THE VILLAGE. PEAKROOM IN BARNETT'S HOUSES JUNIOR FOR HALL.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) AS YEARS PASSED THE OLDER FOLKS STAYED HOME MORE AND THE YOUNGER FOLKS LIKED DANCING IN THE HALL. MORE ROOM. BETTER FLOORS. THE OCCASIONAL TRAVELLING SHOW. WE USED TO DRIVE 6 MILES OR MORE TO GET ANYTHING DONE IN THE HALL. EVERYONE WOULD COME!

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

IN HOMES YES. IN HALLS NOT SO MUCH.

How were babies and small children provided for? BABY BEDS. EXTRA MATRASSES. BLANKETS ETC ON THE FLOOR.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? CROWDED INTO BARN. MOST PEOPLE HAD POLAR SHEDS AND EXTRA HORSES.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

WHIST, KUCHE, PEDRO.

Was there card playing for a prize? NO.

What dances were popular? WALTZES. 2, 3, 4. STEPS. SQUARE DANCES. POLKA'S AND SCHOTTISCH.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. USUALLY NON-DANCERS CAME ALONG JUST TO TALK OR PLAY CARDS IN A CORNER.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

CARDS WERE PLAYED IN ALL HOMES BUT DEFINITELY NO GAMBLING.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Very little. Parties at our homes. Christmas Trees started in a new store building. 2nd Tree in Wauchope Village School. 3rd Tree the new Methodist Church. Wauchope. We called the gatherings Sports Days or Picnics. Had one year, ran races, played games, tea or war, etc.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Not very much. School was for the children to be taught; not for playing.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1912.

What material was it made of? Cement. How large was it? 20 x 40 - 50 feet.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? John Bradstrom of Wauchope Real Estate Dealer and Jack of All Trades. My Uncle.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In the village.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) As years passed the older folks stayed home more and the younger folks liked dancing in the hall. More room, better floors.

The occasional travelling show. We used to drive 6 miles or more to go to anything doing in the hall. Courthouse here!

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

In homes yes, in halls not so much.

How were babies and small children provided for? Bunks, extra mattresses, blankets etc. on the floor.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Crowded into barns. Most people had pole hay sheds and extra horses.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Whist, Ruches, Pedro.

Was there card playing for a prize? No.

What dances were popular? Waltzes, 2-3-4, Steps, Square dances, polkas and Schottische.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Usually non-dancers came along just to talk or play cards in a corner.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Cards were played in all homes but definitely no gambling.
12. What attempts at formality or "manners" do you remember in small towns, such as those mentioned? 

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? 

14. Describe what you remember about chivalry; telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

15. Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? 

How often did it meet? 

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 

When was it organized? 

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 

Describe what you remember of its activities and services. 

Nick Brandt's program so after a year or so our club died out completely.
12. What attempts at a formality or "etiquette" do you remember in small towns, such as those mentioned above? Describe any customs or traditions that you remember.

13. Was the obituary known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social life because noticeable.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to it?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? If so, when was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Nick Frazee's making but didn't seem to have any definite program so after a year or so our club died out completely.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each organization, its location (town, village, etc.), its activities, and the people who belonged (men, women, young people, etc.), whether it included only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

MOD PIAS. Blind man's buff. Nuts & nuts
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name, whether it was a local club, a religious organization, or a social club. Whether it included only a few people or many people, whether it was centered in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding area. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations within the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumblety-peg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? What did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

MUD PIAS. Blind man's buff. Nuts & such
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating etc.? 

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

After dinner, lunch was eaten about 4:30 and all went home early to do chores.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

This game was played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Whist," or other games of chance.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children?

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, rocks, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in South Dakota?

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, or organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as school, community, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnic, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1947 Curling mostly.
6.

31. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

32. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as those in the community (e.g., school or Sunday School picnics), family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

33. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

34. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

35. For what reason was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, stating date of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

37. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1947. Curling mostly.
7.

40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1908-09.

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 25th or July 1st).

Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

41. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

42. Are you interested in reading? Why? (Give reasons)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Why?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? I had no money as a child and could never afford to buy books completely by myself.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling Library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? a few volumes. When was it begun? 1911.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not in our home.
7. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1969

40. Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community pioneer?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? (Give name, month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st.)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible; if not, tell us nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? (Give details)

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? (Give details)

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? (Give details)

47. Have you ever had any travelling library books in your community or school? (Give details)

48. Was there a school library? If so, when was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? (Not in our home)
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Who started it? When was it started? Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this town? In 1910 I had worked in Brandon for a time and subscribed to the Brandon Sun. We also had a newspaper called The Argus sent to us.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. Our family was very interested in reading material and always on the look out for making material and lots of books were read by my twins.
50. Had there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started?

Was it still in existence?

If not, when was it discontinued?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

Our family was interested in reading material and always on the lookout for reading material and lots of books were read by everyone.
59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years? In the West? Description.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years? In the early days, music was an integral part of family life. It was played at parties, dances, and social gatherings.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? "Pretty much the same as above."

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. "Not particularly, only dance tunes."

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. "No."

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well-known or famous in the musical world? Olive names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Explain.

Give details of this collection; telling when you started it; how you became interested in it; any outstanding events connected with it; and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? (use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary)

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community than it was compared with the early days? If so, what is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival or birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.
